titleStmt.title: The censure of the Earl of Berkshire by the Lords in Parliament. Also the examination of foure men being masters of ships, concerning the great Oneal being landed in Ireland, having commission under the great seale of England to kill and slay the English and Scots in that kingdome, and afterward to come into England against the Protestants here. Likewise a relation of the Earle of Essex his marching forward with his forces against the cavaliers. With the manner of Baron Walters being taken, and rescued again the by the cavaliers, five of them being slain.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 9 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The censure of the Earl of Berkshire by the Lords in Parliament. Also the examination of foure men being masters of ships, concerning the great Oneal being landed in Ireland, having commission under the great seale of England to kill and slay the English and Scots in that kingdome, and afterward to come into England against the Protestants here. Likewise a relation of the Earle of Essex his marching forward with his forces against the cavaliers. With the manner of Baron Walters being taken, and rescued again the by the cavaliers, five of them being slain.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE CENSURE OF THE EARL OF BERKSHIRE BY THE LORDS IN PARLIAMENT. Al≈øo the EXAMINATION of foure men being Ma≈øters of ≈øhips, concerning the great Oneal being landed in Ireland, having commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seale of England to kill and ≈ølay the Engli≈øh and Scots in that Kingdome, and afterward to come into England again≈øt the Prote≈øtants here.
Likewi≈øe a Relation of the Earle of E≈ø≈øex his marching forward with his Forces again≈øt the Cavaliers.
WITH The manner of Baron Walters being taken, and re≈øcued again the by the Cavaliers, five of them being ≈ølain.
LONDON, Printed for J. John≈øon. Septemb. 20. 1642.

div.head: THE CENSURE OF THE EARL OF BERKSHIRE, By the LORDS IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: Al≈øo the great Oneals landing in Ireland, with a Commi≈ø≈øion to kill and ≈ølay the Engli≈øh and Scots there, and after to come into England again≈øt the Prote≈øtants here.

Likewi≈øe a true Relation of the Earle of E≈ø≈øex his advancing forward with his Forces again≈øt the Cavaliers: With the manner of Baron Walters being taken and re≈øcued againe by the Cavaliers &c. five of them being ≈ølain.

THe honourable Hou≈øe of Parliament taking into con≈øideration the great number of Delinquents that are now in this Kingdome, many of them ≈øheltering them≈øelves under his Maje≈øties protection, and diver≈øe others that have been lately taken and brought up to London, and impri≈øoned, re≈øolved with all convenient ≈øpeed they could to proceed legally again≈øt them, provided that their proceedings again≈øt them ≈øhould not interrupt the great and weighty affaires
of this Kingdome; and thereupon on Wedne≈øday la≈øt, being the foureteenth day of this in≈øtant moneth of September, according to an Order of the Hou≈øe of Peeres, the Earle of Berk≈øhire, being pri≈øoner in the Tower, was brought to the Barre, and examined concerning his coming into the County of Oxford to a place called Watlington, with ≈øome other per≈øons of quality, with an intent to put in Execution the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, and to ≈øeize upon the Magazine that lay in that towne. Whereupon the ≈øaid Earle pleading that although he thorough the want of a right information concerning the ≈øtate and condition of things as they now ≈øtand in difference betweene the King and Parliament, had mo≈øt unfortunately beene drawn away from the ≈øervice of the Hou≈øe for a time, yet he made many prote≈øtations and declarations of his mo≈øt ≈øincere and hearty de≈øire and endeavour to ≈øerve the Kings Maje≈øty and Parliament in any thing that might be thought acceptable; and humbly ≈øubmitted him≈øelfe to their Lord≈øhips. After which (he being commanded to withdraw) their Lord≈øhips had ≈øome private debate of the matter, and con≈øidering that it was the fir≈øt action that was undertaken by his Lord≈øhip of that nature, and that he had rai≈øed no forces, he was called againe into the Hou≈øe, and upon
his humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, as afore≈øaid, he was enlarged out of pri≈øon, but confined to his owne hou≈øe, and is to appeare againe (at the plea≈øure of the Lords) upon ≈øix houres ≈øummons.

Upon the fifteenth day of this moneth at a Conference of both Hou≈øes, were read the examinations of foure men upon oath taken at Plymmouth, ≈øignifying that the great Oneale that hath been beyond ≈øea many yeares, is now landed in Ireland, and hath brought over with him diver≈øe ≈øhips laden with men and ammunition, to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Rebels in Ireland, and that they ≈øaid they had received a Commi≈ø≈øion from his Maje≈øty under the broad Scale of England, to kill and ≈ølay all the Engli≈øh and Scots in that Kingdome, that ≈øhould re≈øi≈øt them: and that when they have done there, they have the like commi≈ø≈øion for England, but the Parliament have another opinion of his Maje≈øty, and hope that if any ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øions are, they have been obtained by ≈øome ≈øini≈øter meanes without the knowledge or privity of his Maje≈øty, Sir Endimion Porter (not being a ≈øworn Officer, and one that is di≈øaffected to the King and Kingdome) having for diver≈øe moneths together had the cu≈øtody and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the great ≈øeal of England.

Great cau≈øe therefore had the L. Keeper to make ≈øome excu≈øe for him≈øelfe, by ≈øignifying unto the Parliament, that tho≈øe illegall Commi≈ø≈øions and Proclamations lately ≈øent forth under the great Seal, were not pa≈ø≈øed by him, and although in that re≈øpect he hopes for favour, yet it is probable that now he repents he had not followed the example of the Bi≈øhop of Chiche≈øter, Lord Keeper of the Great Seale in the time of Henry the third, who when the King ≈øent to him for the Seale, he refu≈øed to deliver it to his Maje≈øty, but re≈øigned it up into the hands of the Parliament, thinking it mo≈øt proper, that tho≈øe which had power over all cau≈øes, ≈øhould likewi≈øe have the di≈øpo≈øing of the Great Seale of England. But I ≈øhall not further in≈øi≈øt upon this point, therefore I will return to the next particular of my di≈øcour≈øe, becau≈øe in the≈øe times men rather delight in novelties, then in antiquity, and the≈øe times require that men ≈øhould rather ≈øtudie how to ≈øave their heads, then to turn over books.

The Cavaliers per≈øi≈øting in committing many great outrages in Leice≈øter≈øhire, Nottingham≈øhire, and other parts of this Kingdome, the Parliament have ≈øent Letters and In≈øtructions to the Earle of E≈ø≈øex, Lord Generall of the Army, to advance his Forces from Northhampton, to march into Leice≈øter≈øhire, & from
thence into Nottingham≈øhire, for the ≈øetling of the peace of the Kingdome, carrying a petition with him from both Hou≈øes of Parliament in behalfe of them≈øelves and the whole Kingdome, declaring that they have no intent to levy warre again≈øt his Maje≈øty, but de≈øire the peace of the Kingdome, the pre≈øervation of the true Prote≈øtant Religion, the Lawes of the Land, the Priviledges of Parliament, and the liberty and Propriety of the Subject, again≈øt tho≈øe evill Coun≈øellers and Actors that go about to violate and overthrow the ≈øame.

On Saturday la≈øt, being the tenth of this in≈øtant moneth, Baron Walter, being a great Delinquent, was taken at Broadway in the County of Worce≈øter, by the meanes of one M. Stevens, a very religious man, being chiefe, Con≈øtable, & in regard the Sabbath was then approaching, he was kept all that night and all day on ≈øunday at the ≈øaid Stevens his hou≈øe: but (notice thereof being pre≈øently given to the Cavaliers which came that night out of Oxford, they came on ≈øunday night to the ≈øaid towne of Broadway, and be≈øet the ≈øaid Stevens his hou≈øe, and demanded that the ≈øaid Baron ≈øhould be delivered unto them: which being denied, they ≈øet upon the hou≈øe, threatning to beat it downe: but the ≈øaid Stevens having ≈øome muskets in his hou≈øe which had been taken from the lord Lovelace, began to
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
charge upon them out of the windowes, and killed foure or five of them, and perceiving that they could not enter the hou≈øe without the hazard of many of their lives, they pre≈øently ≈øet fire on his barnes, ≈øtables and outhou≈øes, and burnt them down to the ground, which put the countrey into ≈øuch terrour and amazement (not knowing the number of the Cavaliers, nor what ≈øtrength they had, fearing le≈øt the whole town ≈øhould have been fired by them) that many of them began to intercede that the Baron ≈øhould bee delivered unto them: whereupon, with condition of their departure without further injury to the towne, he was delivered unto them: after which they went towards Worce≈øter, and have plundered many hone≈øt mens hou≈øes in the countrey, and ≈øeized on their armes: and it is credibly reported, that they have entred into Serjeant Wilds hou≈øe at Droit (a worthy Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons) and have plundered the ≈øame.
